Bug.Summery: [Merge API] CVS Merge should use IResourceMappingMerger

Lines.Line: 1) We need a RemoteResourceMappingContext to determine the scope of the
operation. To create the proper subscriber, we need the scope. Our current
implementation of RemoteResourceMappingContext needs a subscriber so we are in
a catch-22. We can create a subscriber on the whole workspace for the context
and then discard it and create a more specific one from the scope.
2) The simple merge case should be straight forward but the more complicated
case is the option to perform the merge directly into the workspace. This one
will be complicated.
3) We support ongoing merges in the sync view. We'll want to try and support
this as well.
I have released the first cut at this. For 1) I used a subscriber whose scope is the projects. This assums that a logical model element cannot span projects.
Points 2) and 3) still need to be address and the following issues also need to be addressed:
4) Show only incoming and conflict modes
5) The Edit menu, Show Annotations and Show History need to be added to the context menu
6) There is a Merge and Overwrite action instead of a single Update
7) The participant will leak into the Core synchronizer until persistence is supported
I've done a bit more here. The main points that remain are:
1) Options on merge wizard for a) merge preview, b) attempt headless merge and preview conflicts, c) merge into workspace using "cvs update".
2) Ensure that contents are cached before editor is opened. I think this is the case now but we could optimize the case were the base is the same as the local.
3) Ability to include author in the labels
Fixed

Bug.WithStack:
The CVS Merge wizard should use the IResourceMappingMerger to perform the merges. There are a couple of complications here:
1) We need a RemoteResourceMappingContext to determine the scope of the operation. To create the proper subscriber, we need the scope. Our current implementation of RemoteResourceMappingContext needs a subscriber so we are in a catch-22. We can create a subscriber on the whole workspace for the context and then discard it and create a more specific one from the scope.
2) The simple merge case should be straight forward but the more complicated case is the option to perform the merge directly into the workspace. This one will be complicated.
3) We support ongoing merges in the sync view. We'll want to try and support this as well. I have released the first cut at this. For 1) I used a subscriber whose scope is the projects. This assums that a logical model element cannot span projects.
Points 2) and 3) still need to be address and the following issues also need to be addressed:
4) Show only incoming and conflict modes 5) The Edit menu, Show Annotations and Show History need to be added to the context menu 6) There is a Merge and Overwrite action instead of a single Update 7) The participant will leak into the Core synchronizer until persistence is supported I've done a bit more here. The main points that remain are:
1) Options on merge wizard for a) merge preview, b) attempt headless merge and preview conflicts, c) merge into workspace using "cvs update".
2) Ensure that contents are cached before editor is opened. I think this is the case now but we could optimize the case were the base is the same as the local.
3) Ability to include author in the labels Fixed
Bug.WithOutStack:
The CVS Merge wizard should use the IResourceMappingMerger to perform the merges. There are a couple of complications here:
1) We need a RemoteResourceMappingContext to determine the scope of the operation. To create the proper subscriber, we need the scope. Our current implementation of RemoteResourceMappingContext needs a subscriber so we are in a catch-22. We can create a subscriber on the whole workspace for the context and then discard it and create a more specific one from the scope.
2) The simple merge case should be straight forward but the more complicated case is the option to perform the merge directly into the workspace. This one will be complicated.
3) We support ongoing merges in the sync view. We'll want to try and support this as well. I have released the first cut at this. For 1) I used a subscriber whose scope is the projects. This assums that a logical model element cannot span projects.
Points 2) and 3) still need to be address and the following issues also need to be addressed:
4) Show only incoming and conflict modes 5) The Edit menu, Show Annotations and Show History need to be added to the context menu 6) There is a Merge and Overwrite action instead of a single Update 7) The participant will leak into the Core synchronizer until persistence is supported I've done a bit more here. The main points that remain are:
1) Options on merge wizard for a) merge preview, b) attempt headless merge and preview conflicts, c) merge into workspace using "cvs update".
2) Ensure that contents are cached before editor is opened. I think this is the case now but we could optimize the case were the base is the same as the local.
3) Ability to include author in the labels Fixed

Bug.Summery: [Import/Export] Import Existing Projects into Workspace - disallows duplicates but doesn't explain problem
Bug.WithStack:
I20051101-1204 - import/export > import > Existing projects into workspace
If I select a folder with the same name as a project already in the workspace, the project name doesn't show in the list, but there's no explanation as to why. I haven't used this feature in a long time, so it took me some time to figure out what was going on. I thought the feature didn't work at all.
Then I searched bugs until I found bug #80833 and realized what was going on.
I think an error status should explain that you can't import because the project already exists. There are some ideas floating around about what to do in the case of duplicates. I decided to take the path of least resistance to begin with and just not show the duplicates, but I see that can be confusing at times. see also bug 91715. *** Bug 116011 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Note this related bug: if the project in your workspace has the same name but different casing (e.g. MyProject vs. Myproject) than the project in an archive file, the project in the selected archive file will appear in the list. *** Bug 118923 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 127504 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
It used to be the case, certainly in 3.1 and I think in 3.2M3 that specifying the root folder for Import Projects did a tree search and presented a flat list of all folders containing .project files. (The flattening was a pain.)
The current behaviour is to just add the folder.
When I want to add 6 projects out of 24 it now really tedious. I have to select each indiovidually. It doesn't even remember where I was last.
Please restore the older behaviour, or add the hierarchical tree to the tick selectors so that multiple wanted elements are selectable. The basic behavior of the import existing projects wizards hasn't changed - I still see a flat list. Can you provide steps, screenshots, and some more info about the projects that are in your workspace and the projects in the selected directory. I am not sure what you mean when you say "The current behaviour is to just add the folder."

Bug.Summery: No UI access to the "Search Subfolders" option
Bug.WithStack:
The value of the "Search Subfolders" option is hardcoded in the DirectorySourceContainerDialog. Created attachment 29117 Proposed fix.
This patch contains a dialog that allows to specify a file system directory and set the "Search Subfolders" options. The "Browse" button can be used to open the native directory selection dialog. Created attachment 29118 The title image. Created attachment 29119 The title image Applied patch with a few modifications:
* Allowed 'edit' function to change directory as well as subfolder option * Modified some NLS string/wordings * Persisted 'search subfolder' option in dialog store Please verify, Kevin. Will send images to artist for touchup. Of course, we should add the same editing for a "workspace" folder. Mike, take a look at what I (Mikhail) did for the "File system folder" in the source lookup dialog. We should do a similar thing for "Workspace folders" to allow searching for subfolders.
However, the "check box" for "search subfolders" could be added to the "folder selection dialog" (may require a special selection dialog be created) to avoid having two dialogs (wizard + folder selection). For the case of external folders we have to have to dialogs, as the folder selection dialog is native. Created attachment 30067 further patch
This is a patch for providing access to searching subfolders to the workspace folders option as well.
Please verify Darin. Applied patch. Also added code to allow editing of an existing workspace folder. Verified (and released modified art work).

Bug.Summery: [Import/Export] - Import existing projects into workspace - didn't copy files

source_code.code: // import project from location copying files - use default project location
//only copy the project if it is outside the workspace directory

Lines.Line: - launch a runtime workspace
- in that workspace, create a plug-in project called "Scratch". Accept all
the defaults of the wizard and choose "Custom plug-in wizard" as the template
- when the project has been created, quit the runtime workspace
- now from the host workspace, choose import/export > import > existing
projects into workspace
- select the folder the contains the runtime workspace
- you'll see "Scratch" in the list of projects
- check the checkbox for "copy into workspace"
- the project appears in the workspace as a java project, but it has no
contents at all.
This works for me on Win2K using FAT32 file system for both source and
destination workspaces. I used I20051101-0010 but nothing changed in this code
between then and the noon build. Can you check if there is anything suspect in
your .log file?
hmmm... there is something suspicious in the log from around the time I first
entered this bug:
- "copy files to workspace" is a new feature
- it's common to import a project from another workspace
- the default workspace location on windows has a pathname that will exhibit
the problem.

But I just tried the scenario again, and checked first that there was no "scratch" directory on disk in my host workspace. It still fails as originally described, but there was nothing new in the log. I did the scenario again with a new project name, "Test" and had the same problem, but nothing in the log...
When I reported "no contents" in the project, I was looking from the Java perspective. If I switch to the resource navigator, I can see the following were imported:
scratch/bin/.project scratch/.project
but none of the other files were imported. If I go back to disk and look at the runtime workspace from where everything was imported, I can see that there are many more files/folders that should have been copied.
Created attachment 29130 zip file containing runtime workspace
This is a zip file containing the runtime workspace I'm trying to import from. Expand it into the file system and then select the top level folder of the workspace to try to import the projects. Interesting...I can successfully import the projects using [copy into workspace] if I import from the attached zip. But if I expand the zip and try to import from the file system, I cannot successfully import.
I think I saw a bug earlier (that had been fixed) involving a difference in the separators used for archive files vs. the file system...could it be related to that one? I can troll around for the bug number if you don't know what I'm talking about... the bug that sounds similar (though reversed) is bug #95613. In that bug, the problem was importing from the zip, not the file system. Symptoms seem similar, though. I just expanded the zip and was able to import both projects (from directory) and there are lots of files. Maybe I should get someone using XP to try? It sounds to me like the import of the files isn't even being attempted. What happens is the project is created and then the import operation (to import all the project's files) is setup and run. yes, might be worthwhile. I'm running Windows XP Pro Version 2002, Service Pack 1. How can I check what file system I'm running, in case that matters.... even more interesting:
- I can successfully import (as you did) if I expand the zip file somewhere else and import from it. I just can't import from the original directory (the one I compressed to create the zip file!) That is strange indeed. So it sounds like the file system is not a factor. I just get that info by selecting the drive in file explorer and bringing up the properties - there should be a file system field. What would happen if you tried a different setup? Say, create the plugin project but don't get the new plugin wizard to create all the extra stuff and instead just import some files from somewhere or create some files/directories. Even a simple project (non-Java), with just a few text files imported from elsewhere exhibits the same problem. Importing without copying works as expected. Importing with copying does seem to abort the operation, because you never even see the progress indicator. fyi, I'm running NTFS. I'll try debugging this scenario and report back. I just debugged it down to FileSystemStructureProvider.getChildren. For some reason, the File.list() method is returning null, even though the folder does have children. I tried substituting File.listFiles() to see if anything different happened, but it also returns null. So the wizard believes there are no files to copy.
Here is what the file (folder) in question looks like:
element= File (id=1241) path= "C:\\Documents%20and% 20Settings\\Administrator\\workspace\\scritch" prefixLength= 3
Just checked the javadoc. java.io.File.list() only returns null "if this abstract pathname does not denote a directory, or if an I/O error occurs." So at a minimum we should catch the null case and report that some unknown error occurred.
I tried importing from this same directory using a simple file system import and it worked. Could the problem be that the folder was left open or something in this code path that causes the problem?
cc'ing John in case he has any insight. I just tried importing using the Documents and Settings directory and was able to replicate. I wonder if it's because the directory path has spaces in it? I can investigate further now.
The spaces in the file path are incorrectly being unicode escaped as %20. I found the problem. I get the source path from the project's description (an IProjectDescription), calling description.getLocationURI(). Then call getRawPath() on the URI instead of getPath() which is why the path is messed up when File.listFiles() is called. cc'ing mvm. Do we want to fix this for M3? I think it's worth considering because: - "copy files to workspace" is a new feature - it's common to import a project from another workspace - the default workspace location on windows has a pathname that will exhibit the problem.
Created attachment 29225 apply patch to WizardProjectsImportPage.java do we have tests for import project? maybe we could also put in a test for a directory with spaces (on all platforms)as well.
Yes we should consider for M3 assuming you feel there is no risk in the fix. Both the existing code and patch seem to be vulnerable to NullPointerExceptions. IProjectDescription.getLocationURI() can return null. According to the javadoc, the method only returns null if the location of the project is the default location. Since this wizard always imports from another location then this should never return null. In the wizard, if you select the workspace's location, no projects appear in the list (we should probably show an error message in that case, but that's a separate issue). I guess I was just confused by the presence of this line: if (Platform.getLocation().isPrefixOf(locationPath)) record.description.setLocation(null); In build I20051102-1600, if I import an existing project that is already in the workspace location, and select to copy the contents, I get a NullPointerException. Having said that, it makes no sense to copy the contents if the project is already in the workspace directory. I would suggest something like:
if (copyFiles){ // import project from location copying files - use default project location for this workspace URI location = record.description.getLocationURI(); //only copy the project if it is outside the workspace directory if (location != null) { importSource = new File(location); ... etc ...
Doug, the code you pointed out is only run in an error case. I need to try to recreate that case to see what happens when the copy files option is checked.
John, did you get the NPE by creating a project with name Foo, deleting the project but not the contents (so it still exists on the file system) then importing a project named Foo from a directory with the copy files option checked? Yes, that's exactly what I did. Created attachment 29273 apply patch to WizardProjectsImportPage.java Note: from comment #26, when you import Foo select the direcotry that is the workspace in which you deleted the Foo project but not the contents. Created attachment 29352 apply patch to ImportExistingTest.java
Added a test for this case. Michael, can you check this patch (and the patch for the added test, too). Created attachment 29359 apply patch to ImportExistingTest.java
Original patch no longer valid after change to WizardProjectsImportPage (for bug 80833) was released. Karice, that last patch to the tests doesn't seem to apply even after updating from head. I think this is because another patch to the same class was released earlier today. I'll hold off on submitting the fix until a new test patch can be provided. Created attachment 29445 apply patch to ImportExistingTest.java
Updated test patch. Patches submitted. *** Bug 116452 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified in I20051213-0010

Bug.Summery: Expression builder in Hyperlinks does not allow access to data set
Bug.WithStack:
When I bring up the expression builder in the M2 BIRT 2.0 build, it does not let me select data set values when I am constructing a hyperlink. You need biding the data set before you can access the data set in hyperlink builder. How do a regular report developer know there is a binding step required? Can we show the dataset, and if user selects it, designer will create the binding automatically, and if user switch to a different data set, designer automatically change the binding?
I selected the data element in the table on which I was setting the hyperlink. I then went to the binding tab and set the dataset from which the data element was going to be populated. I saved the report design. I thenk brought up the expression builder for the hyperlink. It did not include the category for the BIRT data set. This is not a problem with binding. It seems like the ability to select from the data set was left out of the expression builder when brought up in the context of the Hyperlink builder. I think it is less user friendly if user needs to first bind a dataset to a report item, and only after that user can use the dataset to build a hyperlink for the report item. It will be better to show all the datasets in the report in the hyperlink builder if no data set were bound to the report item. If a data set is used in the hyperlink, then automatically bind that data set to the report item. But maybe we can have this enhancement in the futre, and for now just fix the bug that data set is left out in the hyperlink builder even when it is a bound to data report item. The new hyperlink builder has resolved this problem. Verified in build 20051220.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When I bring up the expression builder in the M2 BIRT 2.0 build, it does not let me select data set values when I am constructing a hyperlink. You need biding the data set before you can access the data set in hyperlink builder. How do a regular report developer know there is a binding step required? Can we show the dataset, and if user selects it, designer will create the binding automatically, and if user switch to a different data set, designer automatically change the binding?
I selected the data element in the table on which I was setting the hyperlink. I then went to the binding tab and set the dataset from which the data element was going to be populated. It will be better to show all the datasets in the report in the hyperlink builder if no data set were bound to the report item. If a data set is used in the hyperlink, then automatically bind that data set to the report item. But maybe we can have this enhancement in the futre, and for now just fix the bug that data set is left out in the hyperlink builder even when it is a bound to data report item. The new hyperlink builder has resolved this problem. Verified in build 20051220.

Bug.Summery: BIRT Preview preferences have incorrect text
Bug.WithStack:
In Eclipse workbench, choose Window->Preferences. Expand BIRT. Select Preview. The window contains the following text: The selection determines web browsers used to display help documents. If only one browser adapter has been configured, the selection cannot be changed.
This is the text for the Help preferences. The text should be specific to BIRT Preview.
Similarly, in the Preview Server preferences, the additional text for Host name or IP address of local machine is: Leave blank, to automatically determined. In this case, the correct text is identical to the text for the Help Server preferences: Leave blank, to be automatically determined. The text has been corrected. Verified in build 20051220. Fixed in 2.0
Bug.WithOutStack:
In Eclipse workbench, choose Window->Preferences. Expand BIRT. Select Preview. The window contains the following text: The selection determines web browsers used to display help documents. If only one browser adapter has been configured, the selection cannot be changed.
This is the text for the Help preferences. The text should be specific to BIRT Preview.
Similarly, in the Preview Server preferences, the additional text for Host name or IP address of local machine is: Leave blank, to automatically determined. In this case, the correct text is identical to the text for the Help Server preferences: Leave blank, to be automatically determined. The text has been corrected. Verified in build 20051220. Fixed in 2.0

Bug.Summery: [servlets] ServletTemplate in .JETEmitters generates 100 compile warnings
Bug.WithStack:
I have enabled a number of compiler warnings under Window, Preferences, Java, Compiler, Errors/Warnings. These warnings have helped me clean up my code, but the warnings generated by org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.web.ServletTemplate in the hidden .JETEmitters project are distracting. This .JETEmitters project seems to be some kind of hidden project, and ServletTemplate seems to be part of WTP 0.7/0.7.1 used for creating new Servlets.
I would appreciate it if warnings from hidden projects like .JETEmitters were either hidden from the Problems view or fixed. Created attachment 29120 The data from the Problems view.
Here are the compiler warnings created by org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.web.ServletTemplate Created attachment 29121 The current Java source for ServletTemplate
The current Java source for ServletTemplate from Nathan Vick's computer. I presume that this was generated by WTP 0.7.1. Created attachment 29122 Nathan's proposal to fix warnings in ServletTemplate
This attachment contains Nathan Vick's changes to ServletTemplate to fix the 100 compile warnings. I have recently fixed (see bug 218323) all warnings in the .JETEmitter project. This happened in the WTP 3.0 branch. So we may close this bug.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 218323 ***

Bug.Summery: [Doc] New Technology Agent Controller readme.txt file is out of date
Bug.WithStack: Need to update the information in the readme.txt file. Will add general information, install info, how to run sample client, how to build, and will correct the packaging info. readme.txt has been cleaned up, incorporating many fixes suggested by the RAC README.txt file, and generalizing the coverage of the samples so as not to require change any time a sample is added or removed (specifying only SampleClient, our smoke test). Need to included information on steps to build JNI wrappers for the Java agent API. Check in complete with edits As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Need to included information on steps to build JNI wrappers for the Java agent API. Bug.Summery: Out of bounds error when adding new nodes to the fade algorithm
Bug.WithStack: Out of bounds error occurs when adding new nodes. This can be seen when using the context viz view in mylar. This was actually a problem in the stop for layout. The layout needs some work, but this is fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: Out of bounds error occurs when adding new nodes. This can be seen when using the context viz view in mylar. This was actually a problem in the stop for layout. The layout needs some work, but this is fixed.

Bug.Summery: Need jst.common component in bugzilla
Bug.WithStack:
We have one for wst.common. Which subproject's got it right, WST or JST? Nitin, I think this was created when the WST common component became large enough that an owner was assigned. Is there an owner of the JST common component? Do several teams contribute to this component? Since this is a request for a new JST component, I'm changing the component to JST. Naci can decide if we need a jst.common component. I opened it merely because it seemed incongruous to not have a component in Bugzilla when it looks like already we have one in CVS. I only noticed this when I opened bug 114671, where the ValidatorMetaData class appears to live in a jst.common plugin. Admittedly, it wouldn't appear to have anything in the milestone plan as of yet, although I wonder if that's because a great many things just fall into j2ee. To be clear, I'm not advocating it, I just found it strange. FYI - The ValidatorMetaData class is in WST.Validation not a JST common layer. What you were noticing is that it makes use of an extended helper to have a notion of which folders in a project are output folders and can be ignored so as to not have duplicate validation messages.
However, we do have jst.common.annotation plugins, jst.common.frameworks, and jst.common.navigator that it seems like a jst.common component in bugzilla would be warranted. None of these have anything to do with J2EE. Assigning to Naci for comment. I would recommend closing this as "won't fix" until jst.common is larger. Or, until someone has a concrete need.
closing

Bug.Summery: Remote Log Import with Filter does not work due to change in File Transfer behaviour
Bug.WithStack:
Remote log import with a filter from an HP-UX system fails with an error message that indicates the adapter file cannot be found. I'll attache the error window that contains the message. This problem occurs with any log file or log file type. I was using the TPTP 4.1 200510311029 driver.
After debugging this problem I found that this is caused by a change in the Agent Controller file transfer functionality. The log import UI code tries to transfer the modified adapter file with filters to the remote machine. This is a temporary file and it doesn't know what OS the remote machine is so it first tries to transfer the file to c:\ on the HP machine. Previously this request threw an exception and then the code tried to transfer the file to /tmp, assuming the machine was a non-Windows machine. However, now the transfer to c:\ succeeds. It creates a file like /var/tmp/C:\GLA5668.adapter. Because the UI does not expect this it does not send the parser wrapper on the remote machine the correct adapter file name so the parser wrapper fails to find the adapter file. Scott Schneider told me he recently added new functionality that was required by the Test Project so a relative path can be specified for the target file on the putFile call. The file transfer server in the Agent Controller can then create the transferred file in the system temp directory.
To fix this problem, the Log Import UI can be changed to exploit this new functionality. This new functionality was requested in bugzilla feature enhancement 107073 and the intention was to change the log import wizard to use it when it is available. If it is available now we should use it. Created attachment 29123 Error message window Created attachment 29134 Patch to GLAFilterHelper
I tested this patch using 4.1, 4.0, and 3.3 RAC on HP and Windows. You should review the messages thrown in case of errors in the new code I added to ensure correctness. The patch was verified, modified with some minor message handling changes and checked in. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.WithStack: I20051101-1204 Windows XP I switched from flat to hierarchical view in the (unfiltered) problems view. I see the tree blink and dance for several seconds as it populates. It keeps scrolling down as the tree fills in and finally scrolls back to the top to finish the dance. Might be nice to use setredraw here to avoid the dancing tree. Bug.Summery: [DetachedView] Can't use detached views when modal dialog is up
Bug.WithStack:
I thought one of the nice things you could do with detached views was the ability to follow along a cheat sheet while performing the steps on the workbench window, and things like having the tasks view so you can always add/remove things while working in any dialog.
The problem is that you can't do these things because when a modal dialog takes focus from the workbench window, it also takes it from the detached view. This means you have to close the dialog in order to use the detached view.
Can we do it so that you can still work with the detached views while in a modal dialog?
One of the main assumptions a modal dialog makes is that the world is stable while it's up (that's why 'modal' dialogs exist...). What would happen if, while the Properties dialog is up for a Java Project, we delete the project using a detached Package Explorer??
While I don't think that we can accomodate this particular change we are aware that modality as such is a 'bad thing'(tm) and are attempting to reduce its impact on the user experience. For example the new Progress / Jobs handling mechanism allows for many tasks to be run 'in the background', specifically to limit the amount of time 'unavailable' to the User.
Resolution ok.. closing.

Resolution ok.. closing.

Bug.Summery: Put instructions on getting j2ee.jar in a new dependency plugin.
Bug.WithStack: I have discussed the j2ee.jar problem with Harm. He asked me to create a new project (not a plugin) and make it a dependency of the perfmon project. The new project is called org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agent.dependencies. The idea is to make this new project a dependency of all java agent projects. The new project contains a readme file to explain how to get the j2ee.jar. the dependency project has been checked in. closing bug
Bug.WithOutStack: I have discussed the j2ee.jar problem with Harm. He asked me to create a new project (not a plugin) and make it a dependency of the perfmon project. The new project is called org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agent.dependencies. The idea is to make this new project a dependency of all java agent projects. The new project contains a readme file to explain how to get the j2ee.jar. the dependency project has been checked in. closing bug

Bug.Summery: [Wizards] Commit files dialog - finish
Bug.WithStack:
Finish should be disabled, when the user hasn't entered a comment nor selected a template. It is valid to commit without a comment so Finish is not disabled. However, we do prompt the user to confirm when they want to commit without a comment. Created attachment 29171 state Hmm, I'm not really sure ...
When the dialog opens the upper text is empty ... when one clicks on "Finish"
<Click here to enter a commit comment>
will be inserted into the text.
In this specific state the Finish button should be disabled IMO because one has to either select or enter a comment -- so there's no way to "finish" other than providing input.
When the dialog opens the Finish button should be enabled -- I agree with you on that part :) Have you tried this? I did and it works as expected (i.e. if you don't enter text then no comment is sent to the server. The text you mentioned is a hint that you need to enter text but it is not sent to the server). Using eclipse-SDK-I20051101-0010-win32 I can click on Finish and nothing happens ... will try the latest build tonight. Now I understand what is going on. There is a option on the preference page for allowing empty comments. If it is set to No, then Finish is enabled but does nothing. It shoudl definitely be disabled in this case. Soryy about that, I forgot that we had the preference. Forgot about that one too *blush* I have checked behavior described by Sebastian. Eclipse 3.3m4 after finish displays continue prompt. On the prompt there is a checkbox "remember my decision"...
I propose close this bug. Krzysztof, did you change the preference mentioned in comment 6? The preference is on the Team>CVS preference page in the Connection tab. It's the first preference (Allow empty commit comments). Set that to No and see what happens. Ok, I understand. Please give me the dialog class name and I will try to provide the patch. It's in the CommitWizard. Created attachment 58660 Quick Fix
Page is not complete when empty commit comments not allowed but comment is empty. Thanks for the patch Fix released to HEAD. Thanks for the patch. verified

Bug.Summery: Remove debug print statement from org.eclipse.tptp.test.manual.runner.core.internal.model.util.ScriptParser.
Bug.WithStack:
Remove debug print statement from org.eclipse.tptp.test.manual.runner.core.internal.model.util.ScriptParser.
The org.eclipse.tptp.test.manual.runner.core.internal.model.util.ScriptParser#parse (byte[]) method contains a debug print statement (System.out.println(new String (xmlBytes));) that is causing the test script to appear as a message in the test execution log. Bug.Summery: Web projects created programmatically cannot be added to the server

source_code.code: final Action action = new Action( Action.Type.INSTALL, javaFacet14, model );

Lines.Line: 1. Install Tomcat 5 server runtime.
2. Create a Dynamic Web project "a" targetting Tomcat 5.
3. Create a Java file in project "a". Right-click, select Create Web Service.
4. Select to "generate proxy" and "test". Press Finish.
1) The wizard was extremely slow and had repainting problems. This may partially
be due to the fact that there are about 25 builds and resource change events
(ack!) that occur after pressing finish.
2) The project couldn't be added to the server because web services is passing
in 'null' for the project. I've added a better error message in this case, but
web services is also missing a null check.
3) The null is occuring because the J2EE module factory never realizes that
there is a new module in the workspace. The list of modules is cached and
updated whenever a specific list of files change. The initial problem is that
the facet filename changed, and J2EE appears to require that file to exist. I
channges to org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.xml to the list of files
to refresh the modules on.
4) Even with this change, the J2EE module factory still isn't recognizing the
project as a Web module. If I touch the resources in the project is does
eventually wake up though.

Bug.WithStack:
I'm creating a faceted project using ProjectFacetsManager.create(..) and the installing the web 2.4 and java 1.4 facets into it. I'm then setting them as fixed facets and setting a runtime (tomcat 5.0). The project gets created fine but is not recognized as something that can be added to a tomcat 5.0 server. The only differences I noticed between the project I created programmtically and the ones created by using the New > Web > Dynamic Web Project wizard is in the .settings/.component file. The troublesome project has "/src" as the source- path (instead of "./JavaSource") and the context-root property had no value. I manually edited the .settings file and added a value for the context root. I was then able to add the project to the server. Even though the source folder being different is probably not a problem, I think it would be better if what gets set up by default is the same as what the wizard does.
My code is basically doing something like this:
IFacetedProject fproject = ProjectFacetsManager.create(projectName, null, monitor_); IProjectFacetVersion webFacet24 = ProjectFacetsManager.getProjectFacet ("jst.web").getVersion("2.4"); IProjectFacetVersion javaFacet14 = ProjectFacetsManager.getProjectFacet ("jst.java").getVersion("1.4"); Set facetsToAdd = new HashSet(); facetsToAdd.add(webFacet24); facetsToAdd.add(javaFacet14); actions = FacetUtils.getInstallActions(facetsToAdd);
fproject.modify(actions, monitor_); ... fproject.setFixedProjectFacets(fixedFacets); ... fproject.setRuntime(fRuntime, monitor); correction: I manually edited the .component file (there is no .settings file) The WebFacetInstallDelegate does appear to be setting the context-root property. I wonder if the setMetaProperty method does not trigger a save.
As far as the src path is concerned, this one is a bit more tricky. The jst.java facet is used for all of our projects (except ear) and facet install config can only have one default, which is "src". The web project wizard changes this to "JavaSource". You can get your code to behave the same way by adjusting the property in the jst.java facet's data model. Here is how you could do that:
final IDataModel model = (IDataModel) javaFacet14.createActionConfig( Action.Type.INSTALL ); model.setStringProperty( IJavaFacetInstallDataModelProperties.SOURCE_FOLDER_NAME, "JavaSource" ); final Action action = new Action( Action.Type.INSTALL, javaFacet14, model );
Perhaps we should consider switching to using "src" instead of "JavaSource" for web projects to be consistent with other projects... I changed to /src from /JavaSource and fixed the Context Root problem... closing this defect now.... With the 1104_0542 I-driver, if we let the Web service wizard create the Web project, after the wizard finish, the project is not added to the server. It won't even show up as available choice in the Server -> Add/Remove project pop- up. I noticed that the JRE container is missing in the wizard-created Web project. However, even if I go to project properties to manually target it to Tomcat 5, the wizard-created Web project would still not show up in the Server - > Add/Remove project pop-up.
We check the .component file under .settings and noticed that the context-root still has no value. If we manually add the name of the project as the context- root, then the project shows up on the left-hand side in the Add/Remove project to server pop-up.
Rupam, please re-open the defect.
I set a breakpoint at line 108 of WebFacetInstallDelegate.java and examined the value of model.getStringProperty(IWebFacetInstallDataModelProperties.CONTEXT_ROOT)
When I the create the project programmatically, the value is empty. My facet install actions have a null config object so it could just be a problem in the default settings.
Chuck,
I tried the 1104_2243I driver which is supposed to have the fix for this defect. It does fix the problem of no value in the context root for the .component file in the .settings directory. However, the wizard-created project still cannot be added to the server and does not show up in the Add project to server pop-up.
To recreate the problem:
1. Install Tomcat 5 server runtime. 2. Create a Dynamic Web project "a" targetting Tomcat 5. 3. Create a Java file in project "a". Right-click, select Create Web Service. 4. Select to "generate proxy" and "test". Press Finish.
This would create a client Web project "aClient". However, this project cannot be added to the project.
We need to find out what's different between this wizard-created project and the Web project created using the Dynamic Web project. Sending to server component - not sure why this can't be added. Walked through this in the debugger and found the following:
1) The wizard was extremely slow and had repainting problems. This may partially be due to the fact that there are about 25 builds and resource change events (ack!) that occur after pressing finish.
2) The project couldn't be added to the server because web services is passing in 'null' for the project. I've added a better error message in this case, but web services is also missing a null check.
3) The null is occuring because the J2EE module factory never realizes that there is a new module in the workspace. The list of modules is cached and updated whenever a specific list of files change. The initial problem is that the facet filename changed, and J2EE appears to require that file to exist. I channges to org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.xml to the list of files to refresh the modules on.
4) Even with this change, the J2EE module factory still isn't recognizing the project as a Web module. If I touch the resources in the project is does eventually wake up though.
Chuck - It used to be only the component file that was checked for the existance of a Web module, but now even after the facets and component files are updated the factory doesn't recognize the project as a web module. Could this be some sort of ordering difference when creating the Web module in this case, or is there another file that you check before accepting the project as a valid web module? About (1)... Unfortunately, when using the wizard's progress bar there is no way to tell the platform to hold all resource events. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=109202. The only way we found to work around this is to use the modal progress dialog, which allows AVOID_UPDATE flag to be used. This is not just a performance problem. Without holding resource events, we get all sorts of intermittent concurrency problems because a lot of the code that's responding to the events is not synchronized (or not synchronized correctly). I haven't ported the modal progress dialog workaround into WTP code base yet. I will do it early this week. Note that it will only effect wizards building from AddRemoveFacetsWizard, so wtp wizards will not pick up this change until they are converted, which should be later this week. #1 is now tracked by https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=115383. With the 1105_1946 I-driver plus the latest fix in jst.j2ee, jst.j2ee.core and wst.common.modulecore for defect 115190 and 115196, this problem still exist. That is, can't add wizard-created project to server. Dropped to build - need change from Tim as well.... Verified on the I200511090601 build. Kathy is seeing this again on the I200511110103 build The problem is showing up again with the 11110103 driver. If you go through the same steps in comment 6, the Web service wizard returns with the error:
"Error occured when adding module, aClient, to the server"
If you cancel from the wizard and check the project properties and select server. You get the message:
"Set the runtime target and the default server for the project. This project cannot be deployed to a server."
However, if you create another dynamic Web project usin the New dynamic Web project wizard, the project now has the proper target. Has anyone checked whether this is a duplicate of 116010? You can either try the next build or grab the wst.server.core plugin from HEAD and test with that. Tried with the latest org.eclipse.wst.server.core plugin in HEAD and I am still seeing the problem. Basically, when we call ServerUtil.getModule(project) with the newly created project, we're getting back null. Created attachment 29810 JUnit test that can reproduce the bug
The attachment contains a JUnit test case to cover this problem. This way it can reproduced without launching the Web service wizard. The test creates a tomcat 5.0 server, creates a Web project (jst.web 2.4, jst.java 1.4) and then adds the project to the server. To launch it from a dev. environment, just drop it into one of your test plugins, fix up the package and run it as a JUnit plugin test. You'll need to specify your tomcat 5.0 install location in your VM Arguments when running, like this: -Dorg.eclipse.jst.server.tomcat.50=d:\jakarta-tomcat-5.0.28
I verified that the test passes when I200511090601 is my target but fails when I200511110103 is my target. We might consider adding this to the regular test bucket once it's working. Created attachment 29811 Junit test that can reproduce the bug
Made some corrections in the test case. Ok, my bad. I regressed this with a typo in a change I made in the jst.j2ee code this week. As a result, it doesn't catch the last resource change event when the Web facet is added to the project. I've checked in the fix to HEAD.
Chuck - Can you please release the change to J2EEDeployableFactory?
Rupam - Thanks for the testcase. Since you've already gone to the work, let's make sure this one gets added to the build. I've already got a functionally identical test, but it works because I don't use the facet API directly (which changes the ordering that the files are created). Do you want to just add it to the web services bucket, or do you want me to pick this one up? We could also simplify it for either the facets or j2ee bucket. Dropped to build Verified on 1114_1337 I-build.
Tim, please add this JUnit to your bucket.
Chuck, would you be please consider adding a simplied one to the J2EE bucket as well? Verified Verified / Closing
Bug.WithOutStack:
I'm creating a faceted project using ProjectFacetsManager.create(..) and the installing the web 2.4 and java 1.4 facets into it. I'm then setting them as fixed facets and setting a runtime (tomcat 5.0). The project gets created fine but is not recognized as something that can be added to a tomcat 5.0 server. The only differences I noticed between the project I created programmtically and the ones created by using the New > Web > Dynamic Web Project wizard is in the .settings/.component file. The troublesome project has "/src" as the source- path (instead of "./JavaSource") and the context-root property had no value. I manually edited the .settings file and added a value for the context root. I was then able to add the project to the server. Even though the source folder being different is probably not a problem, I think it would be better if what gets set up by default is the same as what the wizard does.
My code is basically doing something like this:
IFacetedProject fproject = ProjectFacetsManager.create(projectName, null, monitor_); IProjectFacetVersion webFacet24 = ProjectFacetsManager.getProjectFacet ("jst.web").getVersion("2.4"); IProjectFacetVersion javaFacet14 = ProjectFacetsManager.getProjectFacet ("jst.java").getVersion("1.4"); Set facetsToAdd = new HashSet(); facetsToAdd.add(webFacet24); facetsToAdd.add(javaFacet14); actions = FacetUtils.getInstallActions(facetsToAdd);
fproject.modify(actions, monitor_); ... fproject.setFixedProjectFacets(fixedFacets); ... fproject.setRuntime(fRuntime, monitor); correction: I manually edited the .component file (there is no .settings file) The WebFacetInstallDelegate does appear to be setting the context-root property. I wonder if the setMetaProperty method does not trigger a save.
As far as the src path is concerned, this one is a bit more tricky. The jst.java facet is used for all of our projects (except ear) and facet install config can only have one default, which is "src". The web project wizard changes this to "JavaSource". You can get your code to behave the same way by adjusting the property in the jst.java facet's data model. Here is how you could do that:
final IDataModel model = (IDataModel) javaFacet14.createActionConfig( Action.Type.INSTALL ); model.setStringProperty( IJavaFacetInstallDataModelProperties.SOURCE_FOLDER_NAME, "JavaSource" ); final Action action = new Action( Action.Type.INSTALL, javaFacet14, model );
Perhaps we should consider switching to using "src" instead of "JavaSource" for web projects to be consistent with other projects... I changed to /src from /JavaSource and fixed the Context Root problem... closing this defect now.... With the 1104_0542 I-driver, if we let the Web service wizard create the Web project, after the wizard finish, the project is not added to the server. It won't even show up as available choice in the Server -> Add/Remove project pop- up. I noticed that the JRE container is missing in the wizard-created Web project. However, even if I go to project properties to manually target it to Tomcat 5, the wizard-created Web project would still not show up in the Server - > Add/Remove project pop-up.
We check the .component file under .settings and noticed that the context-root still has no value. If we manually add the name of the project as the context- root, then the project shows up on the left-hand side in the Add/Remove project to server pop-up.
Rupam, please re-open the defect.
I set a breakpoint at line 108 of WebFacetInstallDelegate.java and examined the value of model.getStringProperty(IWebFacetInstallDataModelProperties.CONTEXT_ROOT)
When I the create the project programmatically, the value is empty. My facet install actions have a null config object so it could just be a problem in the default settings.
Chuck,
I tried the 1104_2243I driver which is supposed to have the fix for this defect. It does fix the problem of no value in the context root for the .component file in the .settings directory. However, the wizard-created project still cannot be added to the server and does not show up in the Add project to server pop-up.
To recreate the problem:
1. Install Tomcat 5 server runtime. 2. Create a Dynamic Web project "a" targetting Tomcat 5. 3. Create a Java file in project "a". Right-click, select Create Web Service. 4. Select to "generate proxy" and "test". Press Finish.
This would create a client Web project "aClient". However, this project cannot be added to the project.
We need to find out what's different between this wizard-created project and the Web project created using the Dynamic Web project. Sending to server component - not sure why this can't be added. Walked through this in the debugger and found the following:
1) The wizard was extremely slow and had repainting problems. This may partially be due to the fact that there are about 25 builds and resource change events (ack!) that occur after pressing finish.
2) The project couldn't be added to the server because web services is passing in 'null' for the project. I've added a better error message in this case, but web services is also missing a null check.
3) The null is occuring because the J2EE module factory never realizes that there is a new module in the workspace. The list of modules is cached and updated whenever a specific list of files change. The initial problem is that the facet filename changed, and J2EE appears to require that file to exist. I channges to org.eclipse.wst.common.project.facet.core.xml to the list of files to refresh the modules on.
4) Even with this change, the J2EE module factory still isn't recognizing the project as a Web module. If I touch the resources in the project is does eventually wake up though.

Could this be some sort of ordering difference when creating the Web module in this case, or is there another file that you check before accepting the project as a valid web module? About (1)... Unfortunately, when using the wizard's progress bar there is no way to tell the platform to hold all resource events. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=109202. The only way we found to work around this is to use the modal progress dialog, which allows AVOID_UPDATE flag to be used. This is not just a performance problem. Without holding resource events, we get all sorts of intermittent concurrency problems because a lot of the code that's responding to the events is not synchronized (or not synchronized correctly). Bug.Summery: support for deprecating extension points
Bug.WithStack:
From time to time we need to refactor plugins and move extension points. Since extension points derive their identity from that of their containing plugin, moving implies a rename. The old ext pt must be left behind for compatibility and the accessing code updated to read both the old and new ext pts when looking for extensions.
Having done this, it would be nice to be able to deprecate the old extension point definition and give developers a chance to update their extensions to use the new extension point.
The deprecation indication could go in the schema though it is unclear that this is shipped in the runtime builds of plugins. Alternatively it could be an additional attribute on the extension point markup itself. In either case, PDE UI would be updated ot have this notion and add the appropriate error/warning markers in the plugin.xml files. Of course, quick fixes would be optimal. :-) I think the deprecation information should be strictly in the schema. In fact, we already support it: Just mark the 'extension' element in the schema as deprecated in the property sheet.
The warning issued by PDE for using a deprecated extension should be improved though. We now issue a generic warning about deprecated 'elements'.
Janek, keep this one in mind as we redesign the schema editor. We should allow people to specify the extension point that should be used instead of the deprecated one. Extensions can be flagged as deprecated in the new schema editor, a suggested replacement extension can also be specified. Deprecated extensions will now get an appropriate warning/error in the plugin editor.
Bug.WithOutStack:
From time to time we need to refactor plugins and move extension points. Since extension points derive their identity from that of their containing plugin, moving implies a rename. The old ext pt must be left behind for compatibility and the accessing code updated to read both the old and new ext pts when looking for extensions.
Having done this, it would be nice to be able to deprecate the old extension point definition and give developers a chance to update their extensions to use the new extension point.
The deprecation indication could go in the schema though it is unclear that this is shipped in the runtime builds of plugins. Alternatively it could be an additional attribute on the extension point markup itself. In either case, PDE UI would be updated ot have this notion and add the appropriate error/warning markers in the plugin.xml files. Of course, quick fixes would be optimal. :-) I think the deprecation information should be strictly in the schema. In fact, we already support it: Just mark the 'extension' element in the schema as deprecated in the property sheet.
The warning issued by PDE for using a deprecated extension should be improved though. We now issue a generic warning about deprecated 'elements'.
Janek, keep this one in mind as we redesign the schema editor. We should allow people to specify the extension point that should be used instead of the deprecated one. Extensions can be flagged as deprecated in the new schema editor, a suggested replacement extension can also be specified. Deprecated extensions will now get an appropriate warning/error in the plugin editor.

Bug.Summery: active search matches should navigate to referring location, not declaration
Bug.WithStack: Currently if you click on the any result of the Active Search (e.g. method that is referencing given landscape) it jumps to the method that is referencing the landscape. Shouldn't it jump to the position where actual reference take the place? Possible alternative could be to activate a standard "Mark Occurences" feature. sTale.
Bug.WithOutStack: Currently if you click on the any result of the Active Search (e.g. method that is referencing given landscape) it jumps to the method that is referencing the landscape. Shouldn't it jump to the position where actual reference take the place? Possible alternative could be to activate a standard "Mark Occurences" feature. sTale.

Bug.Summery: [code templates] The Javadoc of autogenerated get/set method should use the Javadoc of the field
Bug.WithStack:
The simple way is adding a variable ${field_javadoc_first_line} in code template. *** Bug 280176 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** From bug 280176:
If we do something here, we should support generating correct Javadoc, including @param and @return tags.
This would need 2 new code template variables, e.g.
- {@field_javadoc_summary}: For use in main description of getter and setter. Extracts the first sentence as specified here: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/tools/windows/javadoc.html#leadingasterisks
- {@field_javadoc_tag_summary}: For use after @return and @param tags. Extracts the first sentence, removes the dot at the end and makes the first character lowercase
To see where the implementation would go, see references to org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.template.java.CodeTemplateContextType.BARE_FIELD_NAME
Bug.WithOutStack:
The simple way is adding a variable ${field_javadoc_first_line} in code template. *** Bug 280176 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** From bug 280176:
If we do something here, we should support generating correct Javadoc, including @param and @return tags.
This would need 2 new code template variables, e.g.
- {@field_javadoc_summary}: For use in main description of getter and setter. Extracts the first sentence as specified here: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/tools/windows/javadoc.html#leadingasterisks
- {@field_javadoc_tag_summary}: For use after @return and @param tags. Extracts the first sentence, removes the dot at the end and makes the first character lowercase
To see where the implementation would go, see references to org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.template.java.CodeTemplateContextType.BARE_FIELD_NAME

Bug.Summery: allow code assist more conveniently after the dot
Bug.WithStack:
3.2M2
Code assist can be picky about when completion is available.
It could be improved in the following scenario (pretty common and frustrating for users used to VS where this is available (so i'm told))
class A{ void foo(){ Collections.<CODEASSIST> } }
Because it's activated _after_ the dot, code assist is not available here and only beeps sadly.
However, delete the dot and do code assist again and the import appears. _Then_ you can type the dot, and code assist will give you the list of completions you expect.
Essentially, to do what I want I have to do code assist twice when once should be enough. Inline with current work.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 44627 *** Verified for 3.4M3 using I20071029-0010
Bug.WithOutStack:
3.2M2
Code assist can be picky about when completion is available.

However, delete the dot and do code assist again and the import appears. _Then_ you can type the dot, and code assist will give you the list of completions you expect.
Essentially, to do what I want I have to do code assist twice when once should be enough. Inline with current work.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 44627 *** Verified for 3.4M3 using I20071029-0010

Bug.Summery: File comparision does not use syntax coloring
Bug.WithStack:
None of the file comparision seems to use the syntax coloring already available with the editors.
Both Netbeans and JBuilder use syntax coloring for file comparision for any file type. This makes it so much more readable.
Can we please enhance this in Eclipse. What do you mean with file comparison ?
I checked the synchronize view and compare for Java files and both use syntax coloring, however not semantic coloring. I am not sure what you mean by semantic coloring.
I am refering to Syntax coloring not being used for property files and xml files when you compare two files via CVS/Team actions or Local History/Compare actions.
It is the responsibility of the provider of the XML editor to provide the proper extension to compare. Otherwise compare can't know how to color the files.
Can you please open a PR against the plug-in you are using for editing XML files. I am forwarding this to text to take care of the properties file where they contribute the editor for. I have raised bug 114990 for WTP for xml and html file comparison. (In reply to comment #2) > I am not sure what you mean by semantic coloring. > > I am refering to Syntax coloring not being used for property files and xml files
Properties files work fine for me in 3.2 M3. Please provide accurate steps on how to reproduce. See also
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-text-home/development/bug-incomplete.htm
We are still using 3.2M2.
Will check against 3.2M3. I think the problem is with the property file name and how it is associated. All well known names that come with eclipse works fine.
If it is a different name like xyz.props and associated via content-type to the properties file editor it works.
If it is associated via file-association it does not work for "file comparisions" although it opens with the property-file-editor correctly.
Is this a bug ? Should we reopen it ?
Software configuration ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600.xpsp_sp2_gdr.050301-1519: Service Pack 2) ----------------------------------------------------------------------- java version "1.5.0_05" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_05-b05) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_05-b05, mixed mode) --------------------------------------------------------------------- eclipse-platform-3.2M3-win32 eclipse-PDE-3.2M3 eclipse-JDT-3.2M3 xsd-runtime-2.1.0 emf-sdo-runtime-2.1.0 GEF-runtime-3.1 VE-runtime-1.1.0.1 wtp-1.0M8 subclipse-0.9.36 -------------------------------------------------------------------
Compare is not related to the editor itself and hence associating an editor to a file extension or content type has no effect at all on comparing stuff. Comparing content depends on registered file patterns or content types and can currently not be controlled via UI.
Feel free to file an enhancement request against Platform Compare.
Bug.WithOutStack:
None of the file comparision seems to use the syntax coloring already available with the editors.
Both Netbeans and JBuilder use syntax coloring for file comparision for any file type. This makes it so much more readable.
Can we please enhance this in Eclipse. What do you mean with file comparison ?
I checked the synchronize view and compare for Java files and both use syntax coloring, however not semantic coloring. I am not sure what you mean by semantic coloring.
I am refering to Syntax coloring not being used for property files and xml files when you compare two files via CVS/Team actions or Local History/Compare actions.
It is the responsibility of the provider of the XML editor to provide the proper extension to compare. Otherwise compare can't know how to color the files.
Can you please open a PR against the plug-in you are using for editing XML files. I am forwarding this to text to take care of the properties file where they contribute the editor for. I have raised bug 114990 for WTP for xml and html file comparison. (In reply to comment #2) > I am not sure what you mean by semantic coloring. > > I am refering to Syntax coloring not being used for property files and xml files
Properties files work fine for me in 3.2 M3. Please provide accurate steps on how to reproduce. See also
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-text-home/development/bug-incomplete.htm
We are still using 3.2M2.
Will check against 3.2M3. I think the problem is with the property file name and how it is associated. All well known names that come with eclipse works fine.
If it is a different name like xyz.props and associated via content-type to the properties file editor it works.
If it is associated via file-association it does not work for "file comparisions" although it opens with the property-file-editor correctly.
Is this a bug ? Should we reopen it ?

Compare is not related to the editor itself and hence associating an editor to a file extension or content type has no effect at all on comparing stuff. Comparing content depends on registered file patterns or content types and can currently not be controlled via UI.
Feel free to file an enhancement request against Platform Compare.

Bug.WithStack:
Remove legacy IBM/Rational comment/string references.
The TPTP source code and resources (e.g. *.xsd, *.xml, *.html, *.exsd, *.properties, etc.) contains legacy IBM/Rational comment/string references including legacy copyright statements that should be removed for this component unless required for backwards compatibility.
Please use the following TPTP copyright statement:
/********************************************************************** * Copyright (c) 2005 IBM Corporation and others. * All rights reserved. This program and the accompanying materials * are made available under the terms of the Eclipse Public License v1.0 * which accompanies this distribution, and is available at * http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html * $Id$ * * Contributors: * IBM - Initial API and implementation **********************************************************************/
Note: The above TPTP copyright statement is for content contributed by committers work for IBM. As such, the two references to 'IBM' should be swapped with references to the company that originally contributed the content.
Plug-ins containing the legacy IBM/Rational comment/string 'com.ibm':
org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.ui
Plug-ins containing the legacy IBM/Rational comment/string 'Property of IBM':
org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.ui
Note: There is no report that shows these results. They have been derived from searching all files (e.g. *.*) in the above TPTP plugins for the 'Property of IBM' and 'com.ibm' strings. Deferred from 4.1 as per decision made at Platform project meeting (11/2/05) fixed Verified in CVS (HEAD).

org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller

org.eclipse.tptp.platform.agentcontroller
Note: There is no report that shows these results. They have been derived from searching all files (e.g. *.*) in the above TPTP plugins for the 'Property of IBM' and 'com.ibm' strings. Deferred from 4.1 as per decision made at Platform project meeting (11/2/05) Looks like the string is contained in the resource.h files. Since the new AC (src-native-new) is pulling this code unchanged from the RAC (src-native), need to eliminate it from the RAC code (and we will delete the copy of that src from the AC code-base after making some changes in the build of the new AC). See bug 125510 and bug 132019
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 125510 *** *** Bug 114702 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified in CVS.
